text: After the death of Saul, when David had returned from the slaughter of the Amalekites, David had remained two days in Ziklag.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the third day, a man came from the camp of Saul with his clothes torn and dirt upon his head. As he approached David, he fell to the ground prostrate.
speaker: Narrator

text:
David asked him, “Where have you come from?”
He responded, “I fled from the camp of Israel.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
David said to him, “Tell me, what is the report?”
So he reported, “The people fled from battle. Many of the people have fallen and died; even Saul and his son Jonathan are dead.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then David asked the young man who was reporting to him, “How do you know that Saul and his son Jonathan are dead?”
speaker: Narrator

text: The young man who was reporting to him answered, “I happened to be on Mount Gilboa when, in front of me, Saul was leaning on his spear with the chariots and horsemen drawing close.
speaker: Narrator

text: When he turned around, he noticed me. He summoned me, and I responded, ‘Here I am.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
“He asked me, ‘Who are you?’
“I answered, ‘I am an Amalekite.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then he said to me, ‘Stand over me and kill me, for I have been mortally wounded, yet I am still alive.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “So I stood beside him and killed him because I knew that he could not live after he had fallen. Then I took the crown that was on his head and the armlet that was on his arm, and I have brought them here to my lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then David took hold of his clothes and tore them, as did all of the men who were with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: They mourned and wept and fasted until evening for Saul, Jonathan his son, the people of the Lord, and the house of Israel, because they had fallen by the sword.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then David asked the young man who was reporting to him, “Where are you from?”
He responded, “I am the son of one who sought refuge, an Amalekite.”
speaker: Narrator

text: David said to him, “How is it that you did not fear raising your hand to destroy the anointed of the Lord?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then David called to one of the young men and said, “Step forward and execute him.” So he struck him and killed him.
speaker: Narrator

text: But David said to him, “Your blood is upon your own head, since your mouth has testified against you, saying, ‘I put an end to the anointed of the Lord.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then David recited this lament over Saul and Jonathan his son,
speaker: Narrator

text: and he told them to teach the sons of Judah the Song of the Bow. It is written in the book of Jashar:
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your splendor, O Israel, has been slain upon your hills.
    How the mighty ones have fallen.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do not report it in Gath,
    do not announce it in the streets of Ashkelon,
lest the daughters of the Philistines rejoice,
    or the daughters of the uncircumcised exult.
speaker: Narrator

text:
O mountains of Gilboa,
    may there be no rain or dew upon you
    or your bountiful fields;
for there the shield of the mighty was defiled!
    The shield of Saul is no longer anointed with oil.
speaker: Narrator

text:
From the blood of the slain,
    from the fat of mighty,
the bow of Jonathan did not turn back,
    nor did the sword of Saul return empty.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Saul and Jonathan,
    beloved and delightful,
    neither in life nor death will they be separated.
They were swifter than eagles,
    they were stronger than lions.
speaker: Narrator

text:
O daughters of Israel, weep over Saul,
who clothed you in scarlet and jewels,
    who adorned your garments with gold jewelry.
speaker: Narrator

text:
How the mighty ones have fallen in the midst of battle!
    Jonathan was slain on your high places.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
How the mighty have fallen,
    and the weapons of war have perished.
speaker: Narrator

text:
After this, David consulted the Lord, asking, “Shall I go to one of the cities of Judah?”
The Lord responded to him, “Go up.”
David asked, “Where should I go?”
And He said, “Hebron.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So David went up there, along with his two wives, Ahinoam the Jezreelitess, and Abigail the widow of Nabal the Carmelite.
speaker: Narrator

text: And David brought the men who were with him, each man with his household, and they lived in the cities of Hebron.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the men of Judah came and there anointed David as king over the house of Judah, and they informed David that it was the men of Jabesh Gilead who had buried Saul.
speaker: Narrator

text: So David sent messengers to the men of Jabesh Gilead saying, “May you be blessed by the Lord, you who have shown this loyalty to your lord Saul by burying him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now may the Lord show you loyalty and faithfulness, even as I deal kindly with you who have done this thing.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now may your hands be strong and may you be courageous, since your lord Saul is dead and the house of Judah has anointed me as king over them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: However, Abner the son of Ner, commander of the army of Saul, had taken Ish-Bosheth the son of Saul and brought him over to Mahanaim.
speaker: Narrator

text: He installed him as king over Gilead, the Ashurites, Jezreel, Ephraim, and Benjamin, over Israel in its entirety.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ish-Bosheth the son of Saul was forty years old when he began to reign over Israel, and he ruled for two years. However, the house of Judah followed David.
speaker: Narrator

text: The length of time during which David was king in Hebron over the house of Judah was seven years and six months.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abner the son of Ner, with the servants of Ish-Bosheth the son of Saul, went out from Mahanaim toward Gibeon.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Joab the son of Zeruiah, with the servants of David, went out in order to meet together at the pool of Gibeon. They sat down, one group on one side of the pool and the other group on the side of the pool opposite them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Abner suggested to Joab, “Let the young men come forward and compete before us.”
And Joab replied, “Let them come.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they stepped forward and were counted, twelve from Benjamin and Ish-Bosheth and twelve from the servants of David.
speaker: Narrator

text: Each one grabbed his opponent by the head and thrust his sword in his opponent’s side; so they fell down together. Therefore that place was called Helkath Hazzurim, which is at Gibeon.
speaker: Narrator

text: The fighting was very fierce that day, but Abner and the men of Israel were defeated by the servants of David.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the three sons of Zeruiah were there: Joab, Abishai, and Asahel; and Asahel was as fast as a wild gazelle.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Asahel pursued Abner, and as he went, he did not turn to the right hand or to the left from following Abner.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Abner looked behind him and said, “Is that you, Asahel?”
He answered, “It is I.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Abner said to him, “Turn aside to your right or left, overtake one of the young men, and take his equipment for yourself,” but Asahel was not willing to desist.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abner continued still to reason with Asahel, “Abandon your pursuit. Why should I strike you down? How then could I show my face to your brother Joab?”
speaker: Narrator

text: But he refused to desist. So Abner struck him in the abdomen with the butt of his spear, so that the spear came out of his back. He fell there and died on the spot. When all of the others came to the place where Asahel fell and died, they halted.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Joab and Abishai pursued Abner. As the sun was setting, they came to the hill of Ammah, which is next to Giah on the way to the Wilderness of Gibeon.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Benjamin gathered to the rear of Abner into a single formation, and they took their stand atop one of the hills.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abner called to Joab, “Must the sword consume forever? Do you not understand that a bitter taste will result in the end? How long will you refuse to command the people to withdraw from chasing their brothers?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Joab responded, “As God lives, I assure you that if you had not said this, the people would have each pursued his brother throughout the night.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Joab blew a trumpet, and all the people stood still. They pursued Israel no longer, nor did they continue to fight anymore.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Abner and his men traveled through the Arabah all that night, crossed the Jordan, and marched all morning until they returned to Mahanaim.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joab refrained from pursuing Abner, but instead mustered all of the people. There were nineteen men besides Asahel missing from among the servants of David.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the servants of David routed Benjamin and the men of Abner; three hundred and sixty of their men died.
speaker: Narrator

text: They carried Asahel back and interred him in his father’s tomb, which was at Bethlehem. Then Joab and his men traveled throughout the night and reached Hebron at dawn.
speaker: Narrator

text: The struggle between the house of Saul and the house of David endured, but David grew stronger as Saul became weaker.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Sons were born to David in Hebron:
his firstborn was Amnon, by Ahinoam the Jezreelitess;
speaker: Narrator

text:
and his second, Kileab, by Abigail the widow of Nabal, the Carmelite;
and the third, Absalom the son of Maakah the daughter of Talmai, the king of Geshur;
speaker: Narrator

text:
and the fourth, Adonijah the son of Haggith;
and the fifth, Shephatiah the son of Abital;
speaker: Narrator

text:
and the sixth, Ithream, was born to Eglah, the wife of David.
These were born to David in Hebron.
speaker: Narrator

text: While there was war between the house of Saul and the house of David, Abner was strengthening himself in the house of Saul.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Saul had a concubine whose name was Rizpah, the daughter of Aiah, and Ish-Bosheth said to Abner, “Why have you gone in to my father’s concubine?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Abner became very angry over the words of Ish-Bosheth. He said, “Am I a dog’s head that belongs to Judah? Each day I show loyalty to the house of Saul your father, to his brothers, and to his friends by not allowing you to fall into the hand of David. Yet today you are charging me with guilt concerning this woman.
speaker: Narrator

text: May God do so to Abner, and more also, for as the Lord has sworn to David, this I will do for him,
speaker: Narrator

text: to transfer the kingdom from the house of Saul and to establish the throne of David over Israel and Judah, from Dan to Beersheba.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And he could not offer a response to Abner, for fear of him.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Abner sent messengers to David on his behalf saying, “To whom does the land belong? Make your covenant with me, and my hand will be with you to bring over all of Israel to you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He responded, “Very well, I will make a covenant with you, but I require one thing from you: you will not see my face unless you bring Michal the daughter of Saul with you when you come to see me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then David sent messengers to Ish-Bosheth the son of Saul, saying, “Give me my wife Michal, to whom I was betrothed for one hundred Philistine foreskins.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Ish-Bosheth sent for her, and he took her from her husband, Paltiel the son of Laish.
speaker: Narrator

text: But her husband went with her, weeping as he went, as far as Bahurim. Then Abner said to him, “Go. Return.” So he turned back.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abner had a word with the elders of Israel, “In days past, you were seeking David as king over you.
speaker: Narrator

text: So do it now, because the Lord said to David: By the hand of David, I will save My people Israel from the hand of the Philistines and from the hand of every enemy.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Abner also spoke privately with Benjamin. Then Abner went to tell David privately at Hebron all that was received favorably by Israel and the entire house of Benjamin.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Abner, along with twenty men, went to David at Hebron, and David held a festival for Abner and the men who were with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abner said to David, “Let me arise, go, and gather all Israel to my lord the king, so that they may make a covenant with you, that you may rule over all that your heart desires.” So David sent Abner away, and he went peaceably.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the servants of David and Joab came from a raid and brought much plunder with them, but Abner was no longer with David at Hebron, because he had sent him away in peace.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Joab and the whole of the army that was with him arrived, they reported to Joab, “Abner the son of Ner came to the king and he sent him away peaceably.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Joab went to the king and said, “What have you done? Abner came to you. Why is it that you sent him away? Now he is long gone.
speaker: Narrator

text: You know that Abner the son of Ner came to deceive you, to learn of your coming and going, to discern all that you are doing.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Joab left David, he sent messengers after Abner, and they brought him back from the well of Sirah. However, David was not aware of this.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Abner returned to Hebron, and Joab pulled him aside in the gateway so as to speak with him undisturbed. There he struck him in the midsection so that he died on account of the blood of Asahel, his brother.
speaker: Narrator

text: Afterward when David heard of this, he said, “My kingdom and I are forever blameless before the Lord for the blood of Abner the son of Ner.
speaker: Narrator

text: May it fall upon the head of Joab and upon all his father’s house. May the house of Joab never be without one who has a discharge, or who is a leper, or who leans on a staff, or who falls by the sword, or who lacks food.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Joab and his brother Abishai killed Abner, because he killed Asahel their brother at Gibeon in the battle.
speaker: Narrator

text: David said to Joab and all of the people with him, “Tear your clothes, put on sackcloth, and mourn before Abner.” As for King David, he followed behind the bier.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they buried Abner at Hebron, the king raised his voice and wept at the grave of Abner, and all of the people wept.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then, the king lamented for Abner, saying,
“Should Abner have died as a fool dies?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your hands were not bound,
    and your feet were not put in fetters;
as a man falls before the wicked, so you have fallen.”
And all of the people continued to weep over him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then all of the people came to persuade David to eat food while it was still day. But David took an oath, saying, “May God do to me, and more also, if I taste food or anything else before the sun sets.”
speaker: Narrator

text: All of the people recognized this, and it pleased them, as everything that the king did was pleasing to all of the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: That very day, all of the people, all of Israel, understood that it was not ordered from the king to have Abner the son of Ner killed.
speaker: Narrator

text: David said to his servant, “Do you not understand that a great leader has fallen this day in Israel?
speaker: Narrator

text: Today, I am weak, even if an anointed king, and these men, the sons of Zeruiah, are too strong for me. May the Lord repay the evildoer according to his wickedness.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the son of Saul heard that Abner had died in Hebron, his courage failed, and all of Israel was disheartened.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the son of Saul had two men who were leaders of raiding bands. The name of one was Baanah and the name of the other Rekab, both sons of Rimmon the Beerothite, from among the sons of Benjamin. Now Beeroth is also regarded as part of Benjamin,
speaker: Narrator

text: because the Beerothites fled to Gittaim and have been sojourners there until this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Jonathan the son of Saul had a son with crippled feet. He was five years old when the report of Saul and Jonathan came from Jezreel. His nurse picked him up and fled, but in her haste to escape, he fell and became lame. His name was Mephibosheth.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Rimmon the Beerothite, Rekab and Baanah, went out and came to the house of Ish-Bosheth in the heat of the day, as he was resting in his bed at midday.
speaker: Narrator

text: They entered the house as if to get wheat and stabbed him in the abdomen. Then Rekab and his brother Baanah fled to safety.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they entered the house, he was lying on his bed in his bedroom; they struck him, killed him, and beheaded him. Then they took his head and traveled by way of the Arabah all night.
speaker: Narrator

text: They brought the head of Ish-Bosheth to David in Hebron and said to the king, “Here is the head of Ish-Bosheth the son of Saul, your enemy who sought your life. This day, the Lord has given retribution against Saul and his descendent to my lord the king.”
speaker: Narrator

text: David answered Rekab and his brother Baanah, the sons of Rimmon the Beerothite, “As the Lord, who has delivered my life from every distress, lives,
speaker: Narrator

text: when one reported to me that Saul was dead, although he was a bearer of good news in his own eyes, I seized him and killed him at Ziklag, which was my reward for his message.
speaker: Narrator

text: How much more so, when guilty men have slain an innocent man in his own house on his own bed, should I not now require his blood from your hand and wipe you from the earth?”
speaker: Narrator

text: David then gave orders to the young men. They killed them, cut off their hands and feet, and hung them at the pool in Hebron, but they took the head of Ish-Bosheth and buried it in the grave of Abner at Hebron.
speaker: Narrator

text: All of the tribes of Israel came to David at Hebron and said, “We are your bone and flesh.
speaker: Narrator

text: Previously, when Saul was king over us, you were the one leading Israel out and in. Also, the Lord said to you: You will shepherd My people Israel, and you will be ruler over Israel.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So all of the elders of Israel came to the king at Hebron, and King David made a covenant with them before the Lord at Hebron. They anointed David king over Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: David was thirty years old when he began to reign, and he reigned forty years.
speaker: Narrator

text: He reigned over Judah from Hebron for seven years and six months, and he reigned over all of Israel and Judah from Jerusalem for thirty-three years.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king and his men went to Jerusalem against the Jebusites, who were living in the land. They said to David, “You will not enter here; even the blind and the lame will turn you away”—thinking, “David cannot enter here.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Nevertheless, David overthrew the stronghold of Zion, which is now the City of David.
speaker: Narrator

text: David said on that day, “Whoever defeats the Jebusites, let him go through the water shaft to reach the lame and the blind, who are despised by David.” Therefore, it is said, “The blind and lame shall not come into the house.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So David occupied the stronghold, and he called it the City of David. He built on all sides from the terraces inward.
speaker: Narrator

text: David went on and became great, because the Lord, the God of Hosts, was with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: King Hiram of Tyre sent messengers to David with cedar wood, carpenters, and stonemasons, and they built a house for David.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then David understood that the Lord had appointed him king over Israel, and that He had exalted his kingdom for the sake of His people Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: David took more concubines and wives in Jerusalem, after having come from Hebron, and they bore him more sons and daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the names of the children born to him in Jerusalem: Shammua, Shobab, Nathan, Solomon,
speaker: Narrator

text: Ibhar, Elishua, Nepheg, Japhia,
speaker: Narrator

text: Elishama, Eliada, and Eliphelet.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Philistines heard that they had anointed David king over Israel, all of the Philistines went up to search for David, but David heard about this and went down to the stronghold.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the Philistines had come and were spread out in the Valley of Rephaim.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So David asked the Lord, “Shall I go up against the Philistines? Will You give them into my hand?”
The Lord said to David, “Go up, because I will certainly give them into your hand.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So David came to Baal Perazim, and David defeated them there. He said, “The Lord has breached my enemies before me like bursting tides.” Therefore, he named that place Baal Perazim.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Philistines abandoned their idols there, and David and his men carried them away.
speaker: Narrator

text: Once again, the Philistines went up and spread out in the Valley of Rephaim.
speaker: Narrator

text: When David inquired of the Lord, He said, “You shall not go up. Circle around behind them and come against them opposite the trees.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you hear the sound of marching in the tops of the trees, pay attention, because at that point the Lord is going before you to defeat the army of the Philistines.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So David did just as the Lord commanded, and he defeated the Philistines from Geba as far as Gezer.
speaker: Narrator

text: Again David gathered all of the chosen men in Israel, thirty thousand.
speaker: Narrator

text: David and all of the people who were with him arose and went from Baalah of Judah to bring up the ark of God, so named for the name of the Lord of Hosts who sits enthroned among the cherubim that are upon it.
speaker: Narrator

text: They loaded the ark of God on a new cart and brought it from the house of Abinadab, which was on the hill. Uzzah and Ahio the sons of Abinadab were driving the new cart.
speaker: Narrator

text: They brought it with the ark of God from the house of Abinadab on the hill, and Ahio was walking in front of the ark.
speaker: Narrator

text: Meanwhile, David and the entire house of Israel were celebrating before the Lord with all sorts of instruments made of fir wood, on harps, on stringed instruments, on tambourines, on sistrums, and on cymbals.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they came to the threshing floor of Nakon, Uzzah reached out and took hold of the ark of God, because the oxen had stumbled.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord became angry against Uzzah, and God struck him down on the spot for his irreverence. He died there beside the ark of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: David became angry because of the outburst of the Lord against Uzzah; that place is called Perez Uzzah to this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: David feared the Lord that day, and he thought, “How can the ark of the Lord come to me?”
speaker: Narrator

text: So David did not allow the ark of the Lord to be brought to him in the City of David. Instead, David redirected it to the house of Obed-Edom the Gittite.
speaker: Narrator

text: The ark of the Lord remained at the house of Obed-Edom the Gittite for three months, and the Lord blessed Obed-Edom and his entire household.
speaker: Narrator

text: When it was reported to King David, “The Lord has blessed Obed-Edom and everything that belongs to him, for the sake of the ark of God,” David went and brought up the ark of God from the house of Obed-Edom to the City of David with rejoicing.
speaker: Narrator

text: When those who were carrying the ark of the Lord had taken six steps, David would sacrifice an ox and a fattened steer.
speaker: Narrator

text: David danced before the Lord with all of his might, and he wore a linen ephod.
speaker: Narrator

text: So David and the whole house of Israel escorted the ark of the Lord with shouting and the sound of the horn.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the ark of the Lord entered the City of David, Michal the daughter of Saul looked down from the window, and upon seeing King David leaping and dancing before the Lord, she thought contemptuously of him in her mind.
speaker: Narrator

text: They brought the ark of the Lord and set it in its place inside the tent that David had erected for it. Then David offered burnt offerings and peace offerings before the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: When David had finished offering the burnt offerings and peace offerings, he blessed the people before the Lord of Hosts.
speaker: Narrator

text: He distributed to all of the people, the entire multitude of Israel, both men and women, one bread cake, one date cake, and one raisin cake to each one. Then all of the people left, each to his house.
speaker: Narrator

text: David returned to bless his household, but Michal the daughter of Saul came out to meet him. She said, “How the king of Israel has dignified himself today, exposing himself this day in the sight of his servant’s slave girls like one of the rabble might shamelessly expose himself.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then David responded to Michal, “It was before the Lord, who chose me over your father and over everyone in his household, to appoint me ruler over the people of the Lord, over Israel. I was celebrating before the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will humble myself even more than this and be abased in my own eyes. But by the maidservants, of whom you have spoken, I will be held in honor.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Michal the daughter of Saul had no children to the day of her death.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now when the king settled into his house and the Lord had given him rest from all of his enemies on all sides,
speaker: Narrator

text: the king said to Nathan the prophet, “I am dwelling in a cedar house, but the ark of God is sitting in a tent.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Nathan said to the king, “Go, do all that is in your heart because the Lord is with you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: That night the word of the Lord came to Nathan:
speaker: Narrator

text: Go and say to My servant David: Thus says the Lord: Do you intend to build a house for Me in which I will dwell?
speaker: Narrator

text: I have not dwelt in a house since the day I brought the sons of Israel from Egypt until this day. I have been moving about with a tent as My dwelling.
speaker: Narrator

text: Wherever I have moved with all the sons of Israel, have I ever spoken a word to anyone from the tribes of Israel, whom I commanded to shepherd My people Israel, saying, “Why have you not built Me a house of cedar?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now therefore, you will say to My servant David: Thus says the Lord of Hosts: I took you from the pasture, from following after the sheep, to be ruler over My people Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: I have been with you wherever you have gone, and I have cut off all of your enemies before you. I will make your name great, like the great ones across the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moreover, I will appoint a place for My people Israel. I will plant them, and they will dwell in that very place. They will be restless no longer, and the unjust will no longer oppress them, as in former times,
speaker: Narrator

text:
ever since the day in which I appointed judges over My people Israel. I will give you rest from all of your enemies.
The Lord declares to you that He will instead bring about a house for you.
speaker: Narrator

text: When your days are complete and you lie down with your fathers, I will raise up after you an offspring from your body, and I will establish his rule.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will build a house for My name, and I will establish his royal throne forever.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will be a father to him, and he will be a son to Me. When he goes astray, I will correct him with the rod of men and afflictions of the sons of men.
speaker: Narrator

text: My commitment will not abandon him, as I removed it from Saul, whom I deposed before you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your house and dominion will endure before Me forever, and your throne will be established by the Lord forever.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Nathan spoke to David in accordance with all of these words and the entirety of this vision.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then King David went in and sat before the Lord. He said,
“Who am I, O Lord God, and what is my house that You have brought me this far?
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet this was comparatively insignificant in Your sight, Lord God, for You have also spoken about Your servant’s house into the distant future. Is this Your manner with man, Lord God?
speaker: Narrator

text: “What more can David say to You? You know Your servant, Lord God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Because of Your word, according to Your will, You have done all of this greatness to inform Your servant.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Therefore You are great, Lord God. There is none like You, and there is no God except You, according to everything that we have heard with our ears.
speaker: Narrator

text: And who is like Your people, like Israel—a single nation in the land, whom God went to redeem as a people for Himself, making a name for Himself by doing great and awesome things for Your land, before Your people whom You redeemed for Yourself from Egypt, a nation and its gods.
speaker: Narrator

text: You established Your people Israel as Your own people forever, and You, Lord, became their God.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Now, Lord God, confirm forever the word that You spoke regarding Your servant and his house and do as You have spoken.
speaker: Narrator

text: May Your name be magnified forever by saying, ‘The Lord of Hosts is God over Israel,’ and may the house of Your servant David be established before You.
speaker: Narrator

text: “For You, O Lord of Hosts, God of Israel, have revealed a word to Your servant, saying, ‘I will build you a house.’ Therefore, Your servant has found the courage to pray this prayer to You.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now, Lord God, You are God, and Your words are true. You have spoken this good message to Your servant.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now, be resolved and bless Your servant’s dynastic house, so that it may stand before You forever. You, Lord God, have spoken, and with Your blessing, the house of Your servant will be blessed forever.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Afterward, David defeated the Philistines and subdued them, and David took Metheg Ammah from the hand of the Philistines.
speaker: Narrator

text: He also defeated Moab. He measured them with a length of rope, forcing them to lie down on the ground. He measured two lengths of rope to be put to death, but the entirety of one length he allowed to live. So the Moabites became subject to David, bearing tribute.
speaker: Narrator

text: David also defeated Hadadezer the son of Rehob, king of Zobah, when he went to restore his authority over the River Euphrates.
speaker: Narrator

text: David seized from him one thousand seven hundred horsemen and twenty thousand foot soldiers, and David hamstrung all of the chariot horses, save those for one hundred chariots.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Arameans of Damascus came to help Hadadezer king of Zobah, but David defeated twenty-two thousand men of the Arameans.
speaker: Narrator

text: David put garrisons in Aram of Damascus; and the Arameans became servants who bore tribute to David. The Lord helped David wherever he went.
speaker: Narrator

text: David took the shields of gold that were issued to the servants of Hadadezer and brought them to Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: From Betah and Berothai, cities of Hadadezer, King David took great quantities of bronze.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Toi king of Hamath heard that David had defeated the entire army of Hadadezer,
speaker: Narrator

text: Toi sent his son Joram to King David to greet him and bless him on account of his fighting with Hadadezer and his defeat of him, for Hadadezer was an opponent of Toi. Joram brought with him implements of silver, gold, and bronze,
speaker: Narrator

text: which King David dedicated to the Lord along with the silver and gold that he dedicated from all of the nations that he had subdued,
speaker: Narrator

text: that is, from Aram, Moab, the Ammonites, the Philistines, Amalek, and the plunder from Hadadezer the son of Rehob, king of Zobah.
speaker: Narrator

text: So David made a name for himself upon his return from defeating eighteen thousand Arameans in the Valley of Salt.
speaker: Narrator

text: He set up garrisons in Edom. Throughout all of Edom, he set up garrisons, and all of Edom became subject to David. The Lord helped David wherever he went.
speaker: Narrator

text: David reigned over all of Israel, and he administered fair judgments to all of his people.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joab the son of Zeruiah was over the army. Jehoshaphat the son of Ahilud was secretary.
speaker: Narrator

text: Zadok the son of Ahitub and Ahimelek the son of Abiathar were priests. Seraiah was scribe.
speaker: Narrator

text: Benaiah the son of Jehoiada was in charge of the Kerethites and Pelethites. The sons of David were chief ministers.
speaker: Narrator

text: David said, “Is there still anyone left from the house of Saul to whom I may show kindness on behalf of Jonathan?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Now there was a servant from the house of Saul whose name was Ziba. So they summoned him to David. The king said to him, “Are you Ziba?”
He replied, “I am your servant.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
The king said, “Is there no one else from the house of Saul to whom I may show the kindness of God?”
Ziba responded to the king, “There is still a son of Jonathan who is crippled in both feet.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
The king said to him, “Where is he?”
Ziba told the king, “He is at the house of Makir the son of Ammiel at Lo Debar.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So King David sent for and brought him from the house of Makir the son of Ammiel, from Lo Debar.
speaker: Narrator

text: Mephibosheth the son of Jonathan the son of Saul came to David and fell upon his face and bowed down. Then David said, “Mephibosheth,” and he responded, “I am your servant.”
speaker: Narrator

text: David said to him, “Do not be afraid, for I will certainly show you kindness on account of Jonathan, your father. I will return to you every field of Saul, your father, and you will eat at my table perpetually.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He bowed low and said, “What is your servant that you should be concerned for a dead dog like me?”
speaker: Narrator

text: The king summoned Ziba the servant of Saul, and he said to him, “All that belonged to Saul and to all his house, I have given to the son of your master.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will work the ground for him—you, your sons, and your servants. You will bring in the produce so that the son of your master will have food to eat; but Mephibosheth, the son of your master, will always eat at my table.” Now Ziba had fifteen sons and twenty servants.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ziba said to the king, “Everything that my lord the king has commanded his servant, your servant will do.” So Mephibosheth ate at the table of David like one of the sons of the king.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Mephibosheth had a young son whose name was Mika, and all who dwelled in the house of Ziba were servants to Mephibosheth.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Mephibosheth lived in Jerusalem, because he ate continually at the table of the king. Now he was lame in both of his feet.
speaker: Narrator

text: After this, the king of the Ammonites died, and Hanun his son reigned in his stead.
speaker: Narrator

text: David said, “I will show kindness to Hanun the son of Nahash, as his father showed kindness to me.” So David sent a message by way of his servants to comfort him concerning his father, and the servants of David went to the land of the Ammonites.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Ammonite officials said to Hanun, their lord, “Has David honored your father in your eyes by sending comforters to you? Was it not in an effort to search out the city, to scout it in order to overthrow it, that he sent his servants to you?”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Hanun seized the servants of David, shaved half of the beard of each, cut their robes in half so that they were exposed, and sent them away.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they reported what had happened to David, he sent messengers to meet them, because the men were severely ashamed. The king instructed them, “Remain at Jericho until your beards have regrown, then return.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Ammonites saw that they had become odious to David, the Ammonites sent and hired the Arameans of Beth Rehob and the Arameans of Zobah, twenty thousand foot soldiers, and from the king of Maakah, one thousand men, and from Tob, twelve thousand men.
speaker: Narrator

text: When David heard of it, he sent Joab and all the army with the warriors.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Ammonites came out and drew up in battle formation at the entrance of the gate. But the Arameans of Zobah, Rehob, Tob, and Maakah were by themselves in the open field.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Joab saw that the battlefronts were both before and behind him, he selected some from the best men in Israel and lined them up opposite Aram.
speaker: Narrator

text: The remainder of the people he placed under the charge of Abishai his brother, and lined them up opposite the Ammonites.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he said, “If Aram starts to prevail over me, you shall help me, but if the Ammonites begin to prevail over you, then I will come to help you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Be strong and let us fight with resolve for the sake of our people and the cities of our God. May the Lord do what seems good to Him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Joab advanced the people that were with him to fight against Aram, and they retreated from before him.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Ammonites realized that Aram had fled, they retreated from before Abishai and entered the city. Then Joab turned away from fighting against the Ammonites, and he came to Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Aram saw that they had been defeated by Israel, they assembled together.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hadadezer sent for and summoned the Arameans who were beyond the River, and they came to Helam. Shobak the commander of the army of Hadadezer led them.
speaker: Narrator

text: When David was informed of this, he assembled all of Israel. They crossed over the Jordan and came to Helam. Aram was drawn up in formation opposite David, and they fought against him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Aram retreated before Israel. David killed seven hundred charioteers, forty thousand horsemen from Aram, and wounded Shobak the commander of the army so that he died there.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When all of the kings who were subject to Hadadezer realized that they were being defeated by Israel, they made peace with Israel and became subject to them.
From then on, Aram was fearful of further helping the Ammonites.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the spring of the year, the time when the kings go out to battle, David sent out Joab and his officers, all of Israel with him. They brought to ruin the Ammonites and besieged Rabbah, but David remained in Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: One evening when David arose from his bed and was walking on the roof of the king’s house, from the roof he saw a woman bathing; and the woman was very beautiful.
speaker: Narrator

text: So, David sent someone to inquire about the woman. And it was asked, “Is this not Bathsheba the daughter of Eliam, the wife of Uriah the Hittite?”
speaker: Narrator

text: So David sent messengers, and took her; and she came to him, and he lay with her. When she had purified herself from her uncleanness, she returned to her house.
speaker: Narrator

text: The woman conceived. So she sent a message and reported to David, “I am pregnant.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then David sent an order to Joab, “Send Uriah the Hittite to me.” So, Joab sent Uriah to David.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Uriah came to him, David asked about the welfare of Joab, the people, and the fighting.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then David said to Uriah, “Go down to your house. Wash your feet.” So Uriah left the house of the king, and a gift from the king followed him.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Uriah slept at the entrance of the house of the king with all of the servants of his lord; he did not go down to his house.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they reported to David, saying, “Uriah did not go down to his house,” David said to Uriah, “Have you not come from a journey? Why did you not go down to your house?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Uriah responded to David, “The ark, Israel, and Judah dwell in makeshift shelters. My lord Joab and the officers of my lord are camping in the open field. But I may enter my house to eat, to drink, and to sleep with my wife? As you live and as your soul lives, I will not do this thing!”
speaker: Narrator

text: So David said to Uriah, “Remain here another day, and I will send you back tomorrow.” Uriah remained in Jerusalem that day and the following day.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now David invited him to eat in his presence, and he drank until he got Uriah drunk. In the evening, he went to lie down in his lodging with the servants of his lord, but he did not go down to his house.
speaker: Narrator

text: That morning, David wrote a message to Joab and sent it by way of Uriah.
speaker: Narrator

text: He wrote in the message, “Send Uriah to the front of the line where the fighting is heaviest then withdraw from him, so that he may be struck down and die.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So as Joab was besieging the city, he stationed Uriah in a place where he knew fierce men were.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the men of the city came out, they fought with Joab, and some people among those who served David fell; Uriah the Hittite died among them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joab sent word to inform David of all of the events of the battle.
speaker: Narrator

text: He instructed the messenger, “When you finish telling the king all the details of the battle,
speaker: Narrator

text: if his anger rises and he says to you, ‘Why did you approach so near to the city? Did you not know that they might shoot from the city wall?
speaker: Narrator

text: Who killed Abimelek the son of Jerub-Besheth? Did not a woman throw an upper millstone on him from the city wall so that he died at Thebez? Why did you approach so near to the city wall?’ You shall then say, ‘Additionally your servant Uriah the Hittite is dead.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the messenger departed and came to report to David everything that Joab had sent with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: The messenger reported to David, “The men prevailed over us when they came out against us in the open field, but we drove them back to the entrance of the gate.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the archers shot at your servants from upon the city wall, and some of those who serve the king are dead. Even your servant Uriah the Hittite died.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So David replied to the messenger, “Thus you shall report to Joab, ‘Do not allow this thing to dismay you, for the sword devours one as well as another. Sustain your attack against the city and bring it to ruin.’ Encourage him with this reply.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the wife of Uriah heard that her husband was dead, she mourned for her husband.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the time of mourning was concluded, David sent for her and brought her to his house. She became his wife and bore him a son. But the thing that David had done was displeasing to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord sent Nathan to David. He came to him and said, “There were two men in a certain city. One was wealthy, but the other was poor.
speaker: Narrator

text: The wealthy man had a very large flock and herd,
speaker: Narrator

text: but the poor man had nothing except a single small ewe lamb that he had acquired. He nourished it and raised it together with himself and his sons. From his crumbs, it would eat; from his cup, it would drink; and in his arms it would lie. It was like a daughter to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: “There came a visitor to the wealthy man, but he was unwilling to take from his own flock or herd to prepare a meal for the wanderer who had come to him. Instead he took the poor man’s ewe lamb and prepared food for the wanderer who had come to him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: David became very angry because of this man. He said to Nathan, “As the Lord lives, the man who did this deserves to die.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he shall restore the lamb fourfold, because he did this thing, and because he had no pity.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Nathan told David, “You are this man! Thus says the Lord, the God of Israel: I anointed you as king over Israel and I rescued you from the hand of Saul.
speaker: Narrator

text: I gave to you your master’s house and your master’s wives into your arms, and I gave to you the house of Israel and Judah. If this were too little, I would have continued to do for you much more.
speaker: Narrator

text: Why have you despised the word of the Lord by doing evil in His sight? You struck down Uriah the Hittite with the sword, and you took his wife as a wife for yourself. You killed him with the sword of the Ammonites.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the sword will never depart from your house, because you have despised Me and have taken the wife of Uriah the Hittite to be your wife.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Thus says the Lord: See, I will raise up trouble against you from within your own house. I will take your wives before your eyes and will give them to your neighbor, and he will lie with your wives in broad daylight.
speaker: Narrator

text: Although you did it secretly, I will do this thing before all of Israel, and under the sun.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then David said to Nathan, “I have sinned against the Lord.”
Nathan said to David, “Now the Lord has put away your sin; you shall not die.
speaker: Narrator

text: Nevertheless, because by this deed you have utterly scorned the Lord, the child who is born to you shall die.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Nathan went to his house. The Lord struck the child that the wife of Uriah had born for David, and he became sick.
speaker: Narrator

text: David entreated God on behalf of the child. He fasted for a period, and he would go in and lie throughout the night on the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: The elders of his house stood beside him to rouse him from the ground, but he was not willing, nor would he consume food with them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The child died on the seventh day, and the servants of David were afraid to tell him that the child had died. They said, “When the child was alive, we would speak to him, but he would not acknowledge our voices. Now how can we say to him, ‘The child is dead’? He may do harm.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
When David noticed that his servants were whispering to one another, he perceived that the child was dead. So he asked his servants, “Is the child dead?”
They said, “He is dead.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So David arose from the ground, washed, anointed himself, and changed his garments. Then he entered the house of the Lord and worshipped. He then went in to his own house. When he asked, they set down food for him and ate.
speaker: Narrator

text: His servants said to him, “What is this thing you have done? You fasted and wept for the sake of the living child, but when the child died, you arose and ate food.”
speaker: Narrator

text: He explained, “As long as the child was alive, I fasted and wept because I thought, ‘Who knows? The Lord may be gracious to me, so that the child may live.’
speaker: Narrator

text: But now he is dead. Why should I fast? Am I able to bring him back again? I will go to him, but he will not return to me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then David comforted Bathsheba, his wife. He went to her and lay with her, so that she conceived a son. They named him Solomon, and the Lord loved him.
speaker: Narrator

text: So He sent a word by way of the prophet Nathan that he should be named Jedidiah for the sake of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Joab fought against Rabbah of the Ammonites and assumed control of the royal city.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Joab sent messengers to David and reported, “I have fought against Rabbah, and I have occupied the water supply of the city.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now gather the remainder of the people, lay siege to the city, and take it. Otherwise, I myself will capture the city, and it will be called by my name.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So David gathered all of the people and they went to Rabbah, fought against it, and took it.
speaker: Narrator

text: David took the crown of their king from his head, and its weight was a talent of gold and precious stone. It was placed upon the head of David. He brought out large quantities of plunder from the city.
speaker: Narrator

text: He brought out the people who were in it, and he put them to work with saws, and iron picks, and iron axes, and sent them to work in the brick kiln. Thus he did to all of the cities of the Ammonites. Then David and all of the people returned to Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: After this, Absalom the son of David had a beautiful sister whose name was Tamar, and Amnon the son of David fell in love with her.
speaker: Narrator

text: It depressed Amnon to the point of falling ill that Tamar his sister was a virgin, but it was impossible for Amnon to pursue her.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Amnon had a friend whose name was Jonadab the son of Shimeah, the brother of David, and Jonadab was a very crafty individual.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He asked him, “Why are you, the son of the king, so sullen morning after morning? Will you not tell me?”
Amnon told him, “I am in love with Tamar, the sister of Absalom my brother.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jonadab instructed him, “Lie down on your bed and pretend to be ill. When your father comes to see you, say to him, ‘Please allow Tamar, my sister, to come and prepare some food for me. She should make the food here, so that when I see it, I may eat it from her hand.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Amnon lay down and pretended to be ill. When the king came to see him, Amnon said to the king, “Please let my sister Tamar come here to make a couple of cakes, so that I may be nourished from her hand.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then David sent word to Tamar at the house, “Please go to the house of Amnon your brother, and prepare food for him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Tamar went to the house of Amnon her brother, where he was lying. She took the dough, kneaded it, and made the cakes before him. Then she baked them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then she took the baking tray and served the cakes to him, but he refused to eat.
Amnon said, “Send everyone away.” So they all left him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Amnon said to Tamar, “Bring the food into the bedroom that I may eat from your hand.” So Tamar took the cakes that she had made and brought them in the bedroom to Amnon her brother.
speaker: Narrator

text: When she brought them close for him to eat, he took hold of her and said, “Come, lie with me, my sister.”
speaker: Narrator

text: She pled with him, “No, my brother, do not violate me, for such a thing is not to be done in Israel. Do not carry out this awful thing.
speaker: Narrator

text: As for me, where could I escape my disgrace? And you would be like one of the fools in Israel. Now, please speak to the king, for he will not withhold me from you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But he refused to listen to her. So, being stronger than her, he overpowered her and lay with her.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Amnon hated her greatly, so that the hatred with which he hated her was greater than the love with which he had loved her. And Amnon said to her, “Get up, go away.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
She said to him, “No, because this great offense of dismissing me is worse than the other which you did to me.”
But he refused to listen to her.
speaker: Narrator

text: He called his personal servant and said, “Send this woman out from me, and secure the door behind her.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now she was wearing a long robe, because the virgin daughters of the king were clothed in such garments. So his servant put her out and secured the door behind her.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Tamar put ashes on her head and tore the long robe that she was wearing. She put her hand on her head and left, wailing as she went.
speaker: Narrator

text: Absalom her brother said to her, “Has Amnon your brother been with you? Keep silent for now, my sister. He is your brother. Do not take this thing to heart.” So Tamar stayed in the house of Absalom, her brother, a desolate woman.
speaker: Narrator

text: When King David heard about these things, he was very angry.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Absalom would not speak with Amnon, either pleasantly or angrily; but Absalom hated Amnon because he had raped his sister Tamar.
speaker: Narrator

text: Two full years later, the sheepshearers of Absalom were in Baal Hazor, near Ephraim, and Absalom invited all of the sons of the king.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Absalom came to the king and requested, “Your servant has sheepshearers; will the king and his servants kindly go with your servant?”
speaker: Narrator

text: The king said to Absalom, “No, my son, we must not all go or we will be a burden to you.” When he urged him, he refused to go, but gave him his blessing.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Absalom said, “If not, allow my brother Amnon to go with us.”
But the king replied to him, “Why should he go with you?”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Absalom urged him until he sent Amnon and all of the king’s sons along with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now, Absalom had commanded his servant, “Look for Amnon to become carefree on account of the wine. Then I will say to you, ‘Strike Amnon, and kill him.’ Do not be afraid, for am not I myself commanding you? Be strong and brave.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So, the servants of Absalom did to Amnon that which Absalom had commanded. Then the sons of the king arose, each mounting his mule, and fled.
speaker: Narrator

text: While they were on the way, the report reached David: “Absalom struck down all of the sons of the king, and there is not one of them remaining.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the king arose, tore his garments, and lay on the ground, while all of his servants who were standing nearby tore their garments.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Jonadab, the son of David’s brother Shimeah, said, “My lord should not think that they have killed all of the servants who are the king’s sons. Amnon alone is dead, for this has been determined from the day he raped Tamar, his sister, by the very declaration of Absalom.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now, my lord the king should not take this matter to heart, thinking that all of the king’s sons are dead. Instead Amnon alone is dead.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Absalom fled.
Now when the servant who was keeping watch looked up, he saw many people coming on the road beyond him, around the hill.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jonadab said to the king, “See, the king’s sons are coming. As your servant spoke, so it is.”
speaker: Narrator

text: As soon as he had finished speaking, the sons of the king arrived, lifted their voices, and wept. The king and all of his servants also wept loudly.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Absalom fled and went to Talmai the son of Ammihud, king of Geshur, but David mourned over his son every day.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Absalom fled and went to Geshur, he was there for three years.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then King David longed to go out to Absalom, for he was consoled over the death of Amnon.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Joab the son of Zeruiah recognized that the king’s mind was on Absalom.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Joab sent a request to Tekoa and brought from there a wise woman. He instructed her, “Act as if you are observing mourning rites. Put on mourning garments, and do not anoint yourself with oil, but act like a woman who has been mourning over the dead like this for many days.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then come to the king and speak to him in this manner.” Thus Joab put the words in her mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text: As the Tekoan woman spoke to the king, she fell on her face toward the ground and bowed low. Then she said, “Help me, O king.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
The king said to her, “What troubles you?”
She responded, “Alas, I am a widow, and my husband is dead.
speaker: Narrator

text: Furthermore, your servant had two sons. The two of them were fighting in the field, but there was no one to separate them. One struck the other and killed him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the entire family has risen up against your maidservant, and they said, ‘Deliver him who struck his brother, so that we may kill him for the life of his brother whom he killed, and we will destroy the heir also.’ So they will extinguish my remaining ember, and leave my husband neither name nor remnant on the face of the earth.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the king said to the woman, “Go to your house, and I will give orders concerning you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Tekoan woman responded to the king, “May guilt rest upon me and the house of my father, my lord the king, and may the king and his throne be blameless.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The king said, “Whoever speaks to you, bring him to me, and he will not cause you harm again.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then she said, “May the king remember the Lord your God so that the avenger of blood will not continue to destroy, lest they exterminate my son.”
He said, “As the Lord lives, not one hair of your son will fall to the ground.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then the woman said, “Allow your servant to speak a word to my lord the king.”
So he said, “Speak.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The woman said, “Why have you planned like this against the people of God? The king’s speaking this word is like a self-conviction, for the king has not brought back his own banished one.
speaker: Narrator

text: We will surely die and are like water spilled on the ground, which cannot be gathered up again. Yet God does not take away a life; He devises plans so that His banished ones will not be cast out from Him.
speaker: Narrator

text: “So now I have come to speak to my lord the king about this matter because the people have made me afraid. So, I thought, ‘I will speak to the king. Perhaps the king will perform the request of his servant.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the king may accept my request to deliver his servant from the hand of the man who would destroy me and my son from the inheritance of God.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “So, your servant thought, ‘May the word of my lord the king provide rest. For like the angel of God, my lord the king discerns good from evil. May the Lord your God be with you.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then the king answered and said to the woman, “Please do not conceal from me anything that I ask you.”
The woman said, “May my lord the king please speak.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
The king said, “Is the hand of Joab with you in all of this?”
The woman answered and said, “As your soul lives, my lord the king, there is no turning right or left from anything that you spoke, my lord the king, for your servant Joab is the very one who commanded me and placed all of these words in my mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text: In order to change this situation, your servant Joab did this thing; but my lord is wise, as with the wisdom of the angel of God, so as to discern everything happening in the land.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the king said to Joab, “This is what I will do. Go and bring back the young man Absalom.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Joab fell with his face to ground and bowed low and blessed the king. Joab said, “Today your servant knows that I have found favor in your eyes, my lord the king, since the king has granted the request of his servant.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Joab arose and went to Geshur, and he brought Absalom to Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king said, “Let him turn to his own house. He shall not come into my presence.” So Absalom turned to his house and did not come into the king’s presence.
speaker: Narrator

text: In all of Israel, there was no man as handsome as Absalom. From the sole of his foot to the top of his head, there was not a blemish on him.
speaker: Narrator

text: When he cut the hair of his head (and at the end of every year he cut it, for it was heavy on him), he weighed the hair from his head at two hundred shekels, according to the king’s standard.
speaker: Narrator

text: There were born to Absalom three sons and one daughter whose name was Tamar. She was a beautiful woman.
speaker: Narrator

text: Absalom lived in Jerusalem for two full years without coming into the king’s presence.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Absalom sent a message to Joab, requesting that he send him to the king, but he was not willing to come to him. So he sent a second message, but still he was not willing to come.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he said to his servants, “See, Joab’s field is next to mine, and he has barley there. Go, set it on fire.” So the servants of Absalom set the field on fire.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Joab arose, came to Absalom at his house, and said to him, “Why have your servants set my plot of land on fire?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Absalom said to Joab, “I sent a message to you, saying: Come, so that I may send you to the king, asking, ‘Why have I come from Geshur? It would be better for me to be there still.’ Now, let me go before the king, and if there is still guilt with me, may he put me to death.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Joab came and reported this to him. Then he summoned Absalom. So he came to the king, bowed low to him, his face on the ground before the king; then the king kissed Absalom.
speaker: Narrator

text: After this Absalom acquired for himself a chariot, horses, and fifty men to run before him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Absalom would go early and stand beside the way into the gate. When any man who had a dispute concerning which he had come to the king for a judgment approached, Absalom would call to him and say, “Which city are you from?” And he would say, “Your servant is from one of the tribes of Israel.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Absalom would say to him, “Look, your claim is good and right, but there is no one to hear you on behalf of the king.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Absalom would continue, “If I were appointed a judge in the land, then every man who had a claim could come and I would give him justice.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When a man would approach to bow before him, he would reach out, embrace him, and kiss him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Absalom acted this way toward every Israelite who came to the king for a judgment. So Absalom stole the hearts of the men of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: After forty years, Absalom said to the king, “Please allow me to go fulfill my vow that I made to the Lord in Hebron.
speaker: Narrator

text: For your servant made a vow when I was dwelling in Geshur in Aram, saying: If indeed the Lord will bring me back to Jerusalem, then I will serve the Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The king said to him, “Go in peace.” So he arose and went to Hebron.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Absalom sent scouts throughout all of the tribes of Israel, saying, “When you hear the sound of the horn, say: Absalom has become king in Hebron.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now two hundred men went with Absalom from Jerusalem, invited and unsuspecting; they did not know anything.
speaker: Narrator

text: Absalom sent for Ahithophel the Gilonite, the advisor of David, from his city Giloh, while he was offering the sacrifices. Now the conspiracy was strong, for the number of people with Absalom was continually growing.
speaker: Narrator

text: A messenger came to David and said, “The hearts of the men of Israel are following Absalom.”
speaker: Narrator

text: David said to all of his servants who were with him in Jerusalem, “Get up. We must flee or there will be no escape from Absalom for us. Hurry up and leave, or he will soon reach us and bring disaster upon us, striking the city with the edge of the sword.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The king’s servants said to the king, “Whatever our lord the king decides, we are your servants.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the king left with his entire house after him, but he left behind ten women, concubines, to watch over the house.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the king left with all of the people after him, and they came to a stop at the furthest house.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now all his servants passed on beside him, all the Kerethites, all the Pelethites, and all the Gittites, six hundred men who had followed him from Gath, passed on before the king.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king said to Ittai the Gittite, “Why are you also going with us? Go back and dwell with the king, for you are a foreigner and, moreover, exiled from your own place.
speaker: Narrator

text: You came only yesterday. Shall I cause you to go roaming around with us today? I am going where I go. Go back, and take back your brothers with you. Mercy and truth be with you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Ittai answered the king and said, “As the Lord lives and as lives my lord the king, only in the place where my lord the king is, whether for death or for life, there alone will your servant be.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So David said to Ittai, “Go on, pass by.” So Ittai the Gittite passed by, along with all of his men and all of the children and elderly who were with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: The whole land wept with a loud voice as all the people passed by. Now the king was crossing over the brook Kidron, and all of the people were crossing over on the road to the wilderness.
speaker: Narrator

text: And also Zadok and all of the Levites with him were carrying the ark of the covenant of God. They set down the ark of God, and Abiathar came up until all of the people had finished passing from the city.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king said to Zadok, “Take the ark of God back to the city. If I have found favor in the eyes of the Lord, He will bring me back and allow me to see both it and its resting place.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if He should say now, ‘I take no delight in you,’ here I am. May He do to me what seems good to Him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The king also said to Zadok the priest, “Are you not a seer? Return to the city in peace with your two sons, your son Ahimaaz and Jonathan the son of Abiathar.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will wait at the fords of the wilderness until word from you comes to inform me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Zadok and Abiathar returned the ark of God to Jerusalem, and they remained there.
speaker: Narrator

text: David went up the ascent of the Mount of Olives, weeping as he went. His head was covered and he went barefoot. Then all of the people who were with him each covered his head and went up, weeping as they went.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now it was reported to David that Ahithophel was conspiring with Absalom, and David said, “O Lord, make the advice of Ahithophel folly.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When David came to the summit where he would worship God, Hushai the Arkite approached him with his coat torn and dirt on his head.
speaker: Narrator

text: David said to him, “If you pass on with me, you will be a burden to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if you return to the city, you may say to Absalom, ‘I am your servant, O king, as I was a servant of your father. As I was then, so now I am your servant,’ so as to counter the advice of Ahithophel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Will not Zadok and Abiathar the priests be with you there? You shall report everything that you hear from the king’s house to Zadok and Abiathar the priests.
speaker: Narrator

text: Their two sons Ahimaaz the son of Zadok and Jonathan the son of Abiathar will be there with them. You shall send word of everything that you hear to me by their hand.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Hushai, the friend of David, came to the city as Absalom entered Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: When David had passed a little beyond the summit, Ziba the servant of Mephibosheth met him, with a couple of saddled donkeys carrying two hundred loaves of bread, one hundred clusters of raisins, one hundred summer fruits, and one skin of wine.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The king said to Ziba, “Why do you have these things?”
Ziba replied, “The donkeys are for the household of the king to ride. The bread and the summer fruit are for the servants to eat. The wine is for those who become weary in the wilderness to drink.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
The king said, “And where is your master’s son?”
Ziba said to the king, “He is staying in Jerusalem, for he said, ‘Today they will return to me the house of Israel and my father’s kingdom.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then David said to Ziba, “Everything that belonged to Mephibosheth is now yours.”
Ziba replied, “I bow before you. May I find favor in your sight, my lord the king.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When King David came to Bahurim, a man of the family of the house of Saul came out. His name was Shimei son of Gera, and he came out continuously cursing.
speaker: Narrator

text: He threw stones at David and all of the servants of King David, as well as all of the people and all of the warriors who were at his right and left.
speaker: Narrator

text: Shimei said when he cursed: “Come out! Come out! You bloodthirsty man, you scoundrel!
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord has returned upon you all the blood of the house of Saul, in whose place you have reigned. And the Lord has given the kingdom into the hand of your son Absalom. You are taken in your own evil, because you are a man of blood.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Abishai the son of Zeruiah said to the king, “How can this dead dog curse my lord the king! Let me go over and remove his head.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The king responded, “What do you have against me, sons of Zeruiah? Suppose that he curses because the Lord has said to him, ‘Curse David.’ Who shall then say, ‘Why do you do so?’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: David then said to Abishai and to all of his servants, “My son who came from my own body seeks my life, and now also this Benjamite. Leave him alone and let him curse if the Lord has so instructed him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Perhaps today the Lord will look upon my guilt and return kindness instead of his cursing.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So David and his men continued on the road, and Shimei went along on the hillside beside them, cursing, throwing stones, and flinging dust at them as he went.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king and all of the people who were with him arrived at their destination exhausted, but he refreshed himself there.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Absalom and all of the Israelite people entered Jerusalem, and Ahithophel was with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Hushai the Arkite, the friend of David, came to Absalom, Hushai said to Absalom, “Long live the king! Long live the king!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Absalom said to Hushai, “Is this the extent of your commitment to your friend? Why have you not gone with your friend?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Hushai said to Absalom, “No! For whom the Lord, this people, and all men of Israel have chosen, his I will be and with him I will remain.
speaker: Narrator

text: Furthermore, whom shall I serve? Should it not be his son? As I served your father, so shall I be with you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Absalom said to Ahithophel, “Give your advice. What shall we do?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Ahithophel said to Absalom, “Lie with your father’s concubines, whom he left to watch over the palace. When all Israel hears that you have made yourself abhorred by your father, then the hands of all who are with you will be strong.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they set up a tent for Absalom on the roof, and Absalom went in to his father’s concubines in the sight of all of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: In those days, the advice that Ahithophel gave was as when one inquired a word from God. Such was all of the advice of Ahithophel, whether that which he gave to David or to Absalom.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ahithophel also said to Absalom, “Let me choose twelve thousand men so that I may arise and pursue David tonight.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will overtake him while he is weary and weak and strike him with terror; all of the people who are with him will flee. Then I will strike only the king,
speaker: Narrator

text: and I will return all of the people to you. When all return except the man whom you are seeking, all of the people will be at peace.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The advice pleased Absalom and all of the elders of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Absalom said, “Summon Hushai the Arkite so that we may hear what he has to say as well.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Hushai came to Absalom, Absalom said to him, “This is what Ahithophel had advised. Should we do this thing? If not, you should tell us.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Hushai said to Absalom, “At this time, the advice that Ahithophel has given is not good.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moreover, Hushai said, “You know that your father and his men are warriors, and they have been provoked like a bear robbed of her cubs. Your father is a veteran of warfare. He will not spend the night with the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: Even now, he has hidden himself in a ravine or some other place, and when one of them falls in the first attack, whoever hears will say, ‘It was a defeat for the people who follow Absalom.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then even the valiant one, whose heart is like that of a lion, will completely despair, for all of Israel knows that your father is a warrior, and those who are with him are brave.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Therefore my advice is for all of Israel, from Dan to Beersheba, to be completely gathered to you like the multitude of the sand along the shoreline and for you to go to battle in person.
speaker: Narrator

text: We will come upon him in one of the places where he may be found, and we will fall upon him like the dew upon the ground. Neither he nor any of the men who are with him will remain, not a single one.
speaker: Narrator

text: If he withdraws into a city, then all of Israel will bring ropes to that city. We will raze it until it is a valley, until there cannot be found there even a pebble.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Absalom and all of the men of Israel said, “The advice of Hushai the Arkite is better than the advice of Ahithophel.” For the Lord had decided to undermine the prudent advice of Ahithophel, so that the Lord might bring calamity to Absalom.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Hushai said to Zadok and Abiathar the priests, “Ahithophel advised Absalom and the elders of Israel to do one thing, but I advised them to do another thing.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now quickly send someone to report to David, ‘Do not spend the night at the fords of the wilderness, but instead cross over. Otherwise, the king and all of the people who are with him will be swallowed up.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Jonathan and Ahimaaz were waiting at En Rogel. A servant girl would go report to them, and they would go report to King David, because they could not be seen entering the city.
speaker: Narrator

text: But a young man saw them and reported this to Absalom. So the two of them went quickly and came to the house of a man in Bahurim. He had a well in his courtyard, and they went down into it.
speaker: Narrator

text: The wife took a covering and spread it over the opening of the well. Then she scattered grain over it so that nothing could be discerned.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The servants of Absalom came to the woman at the house and said, “Where are Ahimaaz and Jonathan?”
She said, “They crossed over the brook of water.” When they searched, they could not find them. So they returned to Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: After they left, they came up from the well, went, and reported to King David. They said to David, “Arise and quickly cross over the water because thus has Ahithophel advised against you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So David and all of the people who were with him arose and crossed over the Jordan. By daybreak, there was not one left who had not crossed over the Jordan.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Ahithophel realized that his advice was not followed, he saddled his donkey and returned to his house in his own city. He gave instruction to his household, then he hanged himself and died; he was interred in the tomb of his father.
speaker: Narrator

text: David came to Mahanaim as Absalom crossed the Jordan, he and every Israelite with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Absalom had placed Amasa over the army in the place of Joab. Now Amasa was the son of a man named Jether the Ishmaelite, who went in to Abigail the daughter of Nahash and sister of Zeruiah, the mother of Joab.
speaker: Narrator

text: Israel and Absalom camped in the land of Gilead.
speaker: Narrator

text: When David came to Mahanaim, Shobi the son of Nahash from Rabbah of the Ammonites, Makir the son of Ammiel from Lo Debar, and Barzillai the Gileadite from Rogelim
speaker: Narrator

text: brought bedding, metal bowls, ceramic vessels, wheat, barley, flour, roasted grain, beans, lentils,
speaker: Narrator

text: honey, curds, sheep, and cheese from the livestock for David and the people who were with him to eat and use. For they said, “The people are hungry, exhausted, and thirsting in the wilderness.”
speaker: Narrator

text: David mustered the people who were with him, and he set over them commanders of thousands and commanders of hundreds.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then David dispatched the people, one-third under the command of Joab, one-third under the command of Abishai the son of Zeruiah and brother of Joab, and one-third under the command of Ittai the Gittite. Then David said to the people, “I myself will go out with you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the people said, “You should not go, for if we retreat, they will not be concerned about us. Even if half of us die, they will not be concerned about us. But now you are worth ten thousand of us. Therefore, it would be better to assist us from the city.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
The king said to them, “I will do what seems best to you.”
So the king stood beside the gate while all of the people went out by hundreds and thousands.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king commanded Joab, Abishai, and Ittai, “Deal gently with the young man Absalom.” All of the people heard the king instruct the commanders concerning Absalom.
speaker: Narrator
