text: So the people went out toward Israel in the field, but the fighting occurred in the forest of Ephraim.
speaker: Narrator

text: The people of Israel were defeated there by the servants of David. That day the defeat was extensive, twenty thousand men.
speaker: Narrator

text: The fighting spread across the land, and the people consumed by the forest were more numerous than those consumed by the sword that day.
speaker: Narrator

text: Absalom was encountered by some of the servants of David. Now Absalom was riding on his mule. When the mule went under the branches of a very large tree, his head was caught in the tree. He was left in midair while the mule that was under him kept going.
speaker: Narrator

text: One man saw him and reported it to Joab, saying, “I saw Absalom hanging in a tree.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Joab said to the man who was reporting to him, “What? You saw him? Why did you not strike him on the spot, sending him to the ground? I would have given you ten shekels of silver and a belt.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The man said to Joab, “Not even if I had felt the weight of a thousand shekels of silver in my hand would I have laid a hand on the king’s son. In our hearing the king commanded you, Abishai, and Ittai saying: Beware lest anyone touch the young man Absalom!
speaker: Narrator

text: Otherwise, I would have worked falsehood against my own life. For nothing is hidden from the king, and you yourself would have set yourself against me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Joab said, “I will not waste any more time with you.” He took three spears in his hand and thrust them into the heart of Absalom while he was still alive in the midst of the tree.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then ten young men, armor bearers for Joab, gathered around and struck down Absalom, killing him.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Joab blew the horn, the people returned from pursuing Israel, for Joab held back the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they took Absalom, disposed of him in a large pit in the forest, and piled over him a very large heap of stones. Then all Israel fled, everyone to his home.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Absalom in his lifetime had taken and set up for himself a memorial stone in the Valley of the King, for he said, “I have no son by whom my name may be remembered.” So he named the memorial stone after himself; and to this day, it is called the monument of Absalom.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Ahimaaz the son of Zadok said, “Allow me to run and bring the news to the king that the Lord has delivered him from the hand of his enemies.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Joab said to him, “You will not be a man who bears news today; you may bear news another day. Today you will not bear news because the king’s son is dead.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Joab said to the Cushite, “Go, report to the king what you have seen.” The Cushite bowed to Joab, then ran off.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Ahimaaz again said to Joab, “Whatever may happen, let me run also, after the Cushite.”
Then Joab said, “Why is it that you want to run, my son? There is no messenger’s reward for you to obtain.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Whatever happens, I want to run.”
So he said to him, “Run.” So Ahimaaz ran by way of the plain and passed the Cushite.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now David was sitting between the two gates when the watchman went up to the roof of the gate, to the city wall. He lifted his eyes and saw a man running by himself.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The watchman called and told the king.
The king said, “If he is alone, there is news in his mouth.” And he came ever closer.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then the watchman saw another man running. The watchman called to the gatekeeper and said, “Look there is another man running alone.”
The king said, “He also is bringing news.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
The watchman said, “I think that the running of the first one is like the running of Ahimaaz.”
The king said, “He is a good man and comes with good news.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Ahimaaz called to the king and said, “All is well.” He bowed down to the ground before the king and said, “Blessed be the Lord your God who has handed over the men who raised their hand against my lord the king.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
The king said, “Is it well for the young man Absalom?”
Ahimaaz said, “I saw a great commotion when Joab sent the servant of the king, your servant, but I do not know what it was.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The king said, “Step aside and stand here.” So he stepped aside and stood in position.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Cushite came and said, “Good news for my lord the king, for today the Lord has delivered you from those who rose up against you.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
The king said to the Cushite, “Is it well for the young man Absalom?”
The Cushite said, “May the enemies of my lord the king and all who would rise up against you to do harm become as the young man is.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The king was deeply moved and went up to the upper chamber of the gate and wept. As he went he said, “O my son Absalom, my son, my son Absalom! If only I could have given my death in your stead, Absalom, my son, my son!”
speaker: Narrator

text: It was reported to Joab that the king was weeping and mourning over Absalom.
speaker: Narrator

text: The victory that day was turned into mourning for all of the people, for the people heard that day, “The king is grieving for his son.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the people entered the city by stealth that day, as a people who have been disgraced steal away when they flee from battle.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king covered his face and called with a loud voice, “My son Absalom, my son, my son!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Joab came to the king in his house and said, “Today you have shamed the faces of all of your servants who saved your life today, as well as the lives of your sons and daughters, the lives of your wives, and the lives of your concubines,
speaker: Narrator

text: by loving those who hated you and hating those who love you. You have shown today that commanders and servants are nothing to you. I know that if Absalom were alive instead today and all of us were dead, then this would be right in your eyes.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now go out and speak reassuringly to your servants, for I swear by the Lord that if you do not go out, no man will stay with you this night, and this will be worse for you than any calamity that has come against you from your youth until now.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the king arose and took his seat in the gate, and the people were all told, “The king is sitting in the gate.” So all the people came before the king, but the children of Israel had fled, each to his tent.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now all of the people began to quarrel throughout all of the tribes of Israel, saying, “The king delivered us from the hand of our enemies, and he saved us from the hand of the Philistines, but now he has fled from the land on account of Absalom.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Absalom, whom we anointed over us, has died in battle. Now why are you idle to bring back the king?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then David sent word to Zadok and Abiathar the priests, saying, “Speak to the elders of Israel, saying, ‘Why are you last to bring the king back to his house when the word of all Israel has come to the king, to his house?
speaker: Narrator

text: You are my brother. You are my bone and my flesh. Why are you last to bring back the king?’
speaker: Narrator

text: Say to Amasa, ‘Are you not my bone and my flesh? May God do to me, and more so, if you are not commander of the army before me from now on in the place of Joab.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text: He swayed the heart of every man of Judah as though they were one man, and they sent a message to the king: “Return, you and all of your servants.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the king returned and came as far as the Jordan, and Judah came to Gilgal to meet the king and bring the king across the Jordan.
speaker: Narrator

text: Shimei the son of Gera, the Benjamite who was from Bahurim, hastened to go down with the men of Judah to meet King David.
speaker: Narrator

text: With him were a thousand men from Benjamin. And Ziba, the servant of the house of Saul, with his fifteen sons and twenty servants, rushed down to the Jordan before the king.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They crossed the ford to bring the household of the king across and to do what was pleasing in his eyes.
Shimei the son of Gera fell before the king as he was crossing the Jordan,
speaker: Narrator

text: and he said to the king, “Do not regard me as guilty, my lord, or remember how your servant went astray the day when my lord the king went out from Jerusalem. May the king not take it to heart.
speaker: Narrator

text: For your servant knows that I have sinned. Therefore, I have come this day, first from all of the house of Joseph, to go down to meet my lord the king.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Abishai the son of Zeruiah answered, “Shall not Shimei be put to death for this, because he cursed the anointed of the Lord?”
speaker: Narrator

text: David said, “What do you sons of Zeruiah have against me that you should become an adversary to me today? Should any man in Israel be put to death today? For do I not know that today I am king over Israel?”
speaker: Narrator

text: The king said to Shimei, “You will not die.” The king gave him his oath.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Mephibosheth the son of Saul went down to meet the king. He had neither dressed his feet, nor trimmed his mustache, nor washed his clothes from the day the king left until the day he came back in peace.
speaker: Narrator

text: When he came from Jerusalem to meet the king, the king said to him, “Why did you not go with me, Mephibosheth?”
speaker: Narrator

text: He said, “My lord, O king, my servant deceived me. For your servant said, ‘I will saddle the mule for myself in order to ride on it and go with the king,’ because your servant is lame.
speaker: Narrator

text: But he has slandered your servant to my lord the king. Still my lord the king is as the angel of God, so do what seems best to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: For all my father’s house were but dead men before my lord the king. Yet you set your servant among those who eat at your table. What right do I have to cry out any more to the king?”
speaker: Narrator

text: The king said to him, “Why do you still speak of your affairs? I say that you and Ziba shall divide the field.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Mephibosheth said to the king, “Let him even take everything, since my lord the king has come safely to his house.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Barzillai the Gileadite had come down from Rogelim in order to see the king across the Jordan.
speaker: Narrator

text: Barzillai was very old, eighty years old. But he sustained the king during his stay in Mahanaim, for he was a very rich man.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king said to Barzillai, “Cross over with me and I will sustain you with me in Jerusalem.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Barzillai said to the king, “How many days are left in my life that I should go up with the king to Jerusalem?
speaker: Narrator

text: I am now eighty years old. Can I discern what is pleasant from what is harmful? Can your servant taste what I eat and what I drink? Can I still hear the voices of men and women who sing? Why, then, should your servant be a burden to my lord the king?
speaker: Narrator

text: Your servant is merely crossing over the Jordan with the king. Why should the king repay me with this reward?
speaker: Narrator

text: Now allow your servant to return, that I may die in my own city with the grave of my father and my mother. But here is your servant Kimham. He will cross over with my lord the king. Do for him what seems best to you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The king said, “Kimham will cross over with me, and I will do for him what seems best to you. Whatever you require of me, I will do for you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: All of the people crossed over the Jordan. And when the king had crossed over, the king kissed Barzillai and blessed him and he returned to his own place.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king passed on to Gilgal, and Kimham went on with him; all of the people of Judah and half of the people of Israel passed on with the king.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now all of the men of Israel were coming to the king and said to the king, “Why have our brothers, the men of Judah, stolen you away and brought the king and his household across the Jordan, and all of the men of David with him?”
speaker: Narrator

text: All of the men of Judah answered the men of Israel, “Because the king is our close relative. Why are you angry over this matter? Have we eaten at all at the king’s expense? Has he given any gift to us?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
And the men of Israel answered the men of Judah and said, “We have ten shares in the king. Therefore we also have more claim on David than you. Why then did you treat us with contempt? Were we not the first to advise bringing back our king?”
But the words of the men of Judah were harsher than the words of the men of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
There happened to be a worthless man there whose name was Sheba the son of Bikri, a Benjamite. He sounded the trumpet and said,
“We have no share in David,
    nor do we have an inheritance in the son of Jesse;
every man to his tents, O Israel.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So every man of Israel withdrew from following David and followed after Sheba the son of Bikri, but the men of Judah stayed with their king, from the Jordan as far as Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the king came to his house in Jerusalem, he took the ten women, the concubines whom he had left to keep watch over the house, and he placed them in custody. He provided for them but did not go in to them. They were shut up until the day of their deaths, living as in widowhood.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the king said to Amasa, “Summon for me the men of Judah in three days, then present yourself here.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Amasa went to summon Judah, but he delayed beyond the deadline determined for him.
speaker: Narrator

text: So David said to Abishai, “Now Sheba the son of Bikri will cause more harm for us than Absalom. You take your lord’s servants and pursue after him. Otherwise, he will find fortified cities and escape from our sight.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The men of Joab went out after him, along with the Kerethites, the Pelethites, and all of the warriors; and they went out from Jerusalem to pursue after Sheba the son of Bikri.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they were at the large stone which is in Gibeon, Amasa came to meet them. Now Joab was dressed in his battle armor, and fastened on it was a belt with a sword in its sheath at the waist. As he went forward, it fell out.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joab said to Amasa, “Is it well with you, my brother?” and he took Amasa by the beard with his right hand to kiss him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Amasa was not on guard against the sword in the hand of Joab, and he struck him in the midsection spilling his entrails on the ground. He died without being struck a second time. Then Joab and Abishai his brother pursued after Sheba the son of Bikri.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now one of the young men of Joab stood by him and said, “Whoever favors Joab and whoever is for David, let him follow Joab.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Amasa was wallowing in his own blood in the middle of the path. When the man saw that all of the people stood still, he moved Amasa from the path to the field and threw a covering over him, when he observed that everyone who passed by would stop.
speaker: Narrator

text: Once he removed him from the path, all of the men passed by, following Joab in pursuit of Sheba the son of Bikri.
speaker: Narrator

text: He passed through all of the tribes of Israel toward Abel Beth Maakah, also passing by all of the Bikrites. Once assembled, they also came after him.
speaker: Narrator

text: They came and besieged him in Abel Beth Maakah. They constructed a siege ramp against the city, standing it against the rampart. As all of the people who were with Joab were battering the city wall in order to bring it down,
speaker: Narrator

text: a wise woman called from the city, “Listen! Listen! Say to Joab, ‘Come closer so that I may speak with you.’ ”
speaker: Narrator

text:
When he came near, the woman said, “Are you Joab?”
He said, “I am.”
She said to him, “Listen to the words of your servant,” and he said, “I’m listening.”
speaker: Narrator

text: She said, “In former times, they would say, ‘Let them inquire carefully in Abel,’ and thus they would resolve an issue.
speaker: Narrator

text: I am a trustworthy and faithful one of Israel. You are attempting to destroy a city, even a mother, in Israel. Why do you swallow up the inheritance of the Lord?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Joab responded, “Far be it, far be it from me to swallow up or destroy.
speaker: Narrator

text:
That is not true. But a man from the hill country of Ephraim, Sheba the son of Bikri by name, has lifted his hand against King David. Only deliver him, and I will depart from the city.”
And the woman said to Joab, “His head will be thrown to you over the wall.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The woman, with her wisdom, came to all of the people in the city, and they cut off the head of Sheba the son of Bikri. When they threw it to Joab, he blew the horn, and they dispersed from the city, each going to his own tent. Joab returned to Jerusalem to the king.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Joab was over the entire army of Israel. Benaiah the son of Jehoiada was over the Kerethites and Pelethites.
speaker: Narrator

text: Adoniram was over conscripted labor. Jehoshaphat the son of Ahilud was secretary.
speaker: Narrator

text: Sheva was scribe. Zadok and Abiathar were priests,
speaker: Narrator

text: and also Ira the Jairite was priest to David.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now there was a famine in the days of David for three years, year after year; and David called upon the Lord. The Lord said, “There is blood guilt upon Saul and upon his house because he put the Gibeonites to death.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the king summoned the Gibeonites and spoke to them. Now the Gibeonites were not from the children of Israel. Instead they were a remnant of the Amorites. Although the children of Israel had made a pact with them, Saul attempted to destroy them in his zeal for the people of Israel and Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text: David said to the Gibeonites, “What must I do for you, and with what may I appease you that you may bless the inheritance of the Lord?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Gibeonites said to him, “We have no concern for silver or gold from Saul or his household, nor is it for us to put any man in Israel to death.”
He said to them, “What are you saying I should do for you?”
speaker: Narrator

text: They said to the king, “Regarding the man who put an end to us and planned to exterminate us from the entire territory of Israel,
speaker: Narrator

text:
let seven of his male descendants be handed over to us, and we will hang them before the Lord at Gibeah of Saul, the chosen one of the Lord.”
The king said, “I will hand them over.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the king spared Mephibosheth the son of Jonathan, the son of Saul on account of the oath of the Lord that was between them, between David and Jonathan the son of Saul.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the king took the two sons of Rizpah the daughter of Aiah, Armoni and Mephibosheth, whom she had born to Saul, and the five sons of Michal the daughter of Saul, whom she had born to Adriel the son of Barzillai the Meholathite.
speaker: Narrator

text: He delivered them into the hands of the Gibeonites, and they hanged them on the mountain before the Lord; the seven of them fell together. They were put to death in the first days of harvest, in the beginning of the barley harvest.
speaker: Narrator

text: Rizpah the daughter of Aiah took sackcloth and spread it for herself on the rock, from the beginning of the harvest until the rains poured on them from heaven. She did not allow the birds of the air to rest on them by day nor the animals of the field by night.
speaker: Narrator

text: When it was reported to David that which Rizpah the daughter of Aiah, the concubine of Saul, had done,
speaker: Narrator

text: David went and took the bones of Saul and the bones of Jonathan his son from the men of Jabesh Gilead who had secretly taken them from the plaza in Beth Shan, where the Philistines had hung them the day the Philistines struck down Saul on Gilboa.
speaker: Narrator

text: He brought up the bones of Saul and the bones of Jonathan his son from there, and they gathered the bones of those who had been hanged.
speaker: Narrator

text: They interred the bones of Saul and Jonathan his son in the land of Benjamin at Zela, in the tomb of Kish, his father. They did everything that the king commanded. After that God was entreated regarding the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now once again there was a battle between the Philistines and Israel. So David went down and his servants with him to fight the Philistines, and David grew weary.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Ishbi-Benob, who was among the descendants of the giant and was girded with new weaponry, had a spear weighing three hundred bronze shekels and had said that he would strike David down.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Abishai the son of Zeruiah came to his aid. He struck down the Philistine and killed him. Then the men of David made an oath with him, saying, “You shall no longer come out with us to battle, so that you do not extinguish the lamp of Israel.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now afterwards there was again a battle with the Philistines at Gob. Then Sibbekai the Hushathite struck down Saph, who was among the descendants of the giant.
speaker: Narrator

text: Once again, there was a battle with the Philistines at Gob. On this occasion, Elhanan the son of Jaare-Oregim the Bethlehemite struck down Goliath the Gittite, whose spear shaft was like a weaver’s beam.
speaker: Narrator

text: Once again, there was war at Gath. There was a man of stature who had six fingers on each hand and six toes on each foot, twenty-four in number. Now he also was born to the giant.
speaker: Narrator

text: When he taunted Israel, Jonathan the son of Shimeah, the brother of David, struck him down.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now these four were born to the giant in Gath, and they fell by the hand of David and by the hand of his servants.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now on the day the Lord delivered him from the hand of all of his enemies and from the hand of Saul, David spoke to the Lord the words of this song.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He said:
The Lord is my rock and my fortress and my deliverer;
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
I call upon the Lord, who is praiseworthy,
    and I am saved from my enemies.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When the waves of death encompassed me,
    the currents of destruction made me afraid.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The ropes of Sheol were wrapped around me;
    the snares of death were opposite me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
In my distress I called on the Lord,
    and cried out to my God;
from His temple He heard my voice.
    My cry reached His ears.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

text:
He bowed the heaven as He came down,
    with thick darkness under His feet.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He rode upon a cherub as He flew,
    and appeared upon the wings of the wind.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He made darkness canopies around Him,
    dark waters and thick clouds of the skies.
speaker: Narrator

text:
From the brightness before Him
    embers of fire are kindled.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord thundered from heaven,
    and the Most High uttered His voice.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He sent out arrows and dispersed them;
    with lightning He sent them into confusion.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The channels of the sea appeared,
    the foundations of the world were exposed
with the rebuke of the Lord,
    from the blast of breath from His nostrils.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He reached from on high and took me;
    He drew me out of mighty waters.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
They confronted me in the day of my disaster,
    but the Lord was my support.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He brought me to the open expanse;
    He rescued me, for He delighted in me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord did for me according to my righteousness;
    according to the cleanness of my hands He recompensed me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For I have kept the ways of the Lord,
    and I have not become guilty against my God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For all His judgments are before me,
    and I have not abandoned His statutes.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I am blameless toward Him,
    and I have kept myself from guilt.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord has recompensed me according to my righteousness,
    according to my cleanness in His sight.
speaker: Narrator

text:
With the faithful You prove Yourself faithful;
    with the blameless You prove Yourself blameless;
speaker: Narrator

text:
with the pure You show Yourself pure;
    but with the perverse You show Yourself shrewd.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You deliver a humble people;
    but Your eyes are upon the exalted to bring them down.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For You are my lamp, O Lord;
    the Lord illuminates my darkness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For by You I can run over a channel;
    by my God I can leap over a wall.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
For who is God except the Lord?
    And who is a rock except our God?
speaker: Narrator

text:
God is my strong fortress,
    and He sets the blameless on His way.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He makes my feet like hinds’ feet;
    He sets me on my high places.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He trains my hand for battle,
    so that my arm may bend a bow of bronze.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You have given me a shield of Your salvation,
    and Your humility has made me great.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You widen my stride under me,
    and my feet do stagger.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I pursued my enemies and destroyed them;
    I did not turn back until they were consumed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I consumed them and shattered them so that they did not rise;
    they fell under my feet.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You girded me with strength for the battle;
    You subjugated under me those who rose up against me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You caused my enemies to retreat from me;
    I destroyed those who hated me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They looked, but there was no one to save them,
    to the Lord, but He did not respond.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I crushed them like the dust of the land,
    like the mud of the streets, I ground them and stamped them down.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Foreigners submit to me, cringing;
    as soon as they hear, they obey me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Foreigners lose heart;
    they gird themselves as they leave their fortresses.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord lives; blessed be my rock.
    May the God of the rock of my salvation be exalted,
speaker: Narrator

text:
the God who gave me retribution
    and brought down peoples under me,
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Therefore, I praise You, O Lord, among the nations;
    I sing praises to Your name.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He is a tower of salvation for His king,
    and He acts faithfully toward His anointed,
    toward David and his descendants forever.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Now these are the last words of David:
The oracle of David the son of Jesse,
    the oracle of the man who was raised on high,
the anointed of the God of Jacob,
    and the favorite psalmist of Israel:
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Spirit of the Lord spoke by me,
    and His word was on my tongue.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The God of Israel said,
    the Rock of Israel spoke to me:
He who rules over man justly,
    who rules in the fear of God,
speaker: Narrator

text:
is like the light of the morning when the sun rises,
    a morning with no clouds,
gleaming after the rain
    like grass from the land.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Is not my house like this with God?
    For He made an everlasting covenant with me,
    ordered in all things and secure.
For this is all my salvation and all my desire;
    will He not make it flourish?
speaker: Narrator

text:
But the worthless individual is like a thorn tossed away, all of them,
    for they cannot be taken with the hand.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But the man who touches them
    must have an iron implement and the shaft of a spear,
    and they must be burned with fire on the spot.
speaker: Narrator

text:
These are the names of the warriors whom David had:
Josheb-Basshebeth, a Tahkemonite, was head of the three. He was also known as Adino the Eznite, on account of eight hundred slain on one occasion.
speaker: Narrator

text: After him was Eleazar the son of Dodai the son of Ahohi. He was among the three warriors with David when they defied the Philistines who were gathered together there to fight when the men of Israel withdrew.
speaker: Narrator

text: He arose and attacked the Philistines until his hand grew weary and stuck to the sword. The Lord brought about a great victory that day, and the people returned only to plunder.
speaker: Narrator

text: After him was Shammah the son of Agee the Hararite. The Philistines had gathered into a troop, where the plot of the field was full of lentils, and the people fled before the Philistines.
speaker: Narrator

text: He took his stand in the midst of the plot of land, defended it, and defeated the Philistines. The Lord brought about a great victory.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then three of the thirty chief men went down and came to David at the cave of Adullam during the harvest. Now the Philistine army was in the Valley of Rephaim.
speaker: Narrator

text: At that time, David was in the stronghold while the Philistine garrison was at Bethlehem.
speaker: Narrator

text: David said longingly, “O that someone would give me a drink of water from the well in Bethlehem by the gate!”
speaker: Narrator

text: The three warriors breached the Philistine camp and drew up water from the well in Bethlehem by the gate, and they brought it to David. However, he was not willing to drink it, so he poured it out as a drink offering to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He said, “Far be it from me, O Lord, to drink this, the blood of the men who risked their lives.” So he was not willing to drink it.
These things the three warriors did.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Abishai, the brother of Joab and son of Zeruiah, was chief of the thirty. He wielded his spear against three hundred men and killed them, and won a name beside the three.
speaker: Narrator

text: Was he more honored than the three? He became their commander, but he did not attain to the three.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Benaiah the son of Jehoiada was a valiant man of Kabzeel, who had done great acts. He struck down two sons of Ariel of Moab. He also went down and killed a lion in the middle of a pit on a snowy day.
speaker: Narrator

text: He struck down an Egyptian, an impressive man. Now the Egyptian had a spear in his hand, but Benaiah went down to him with a staff, seized the spear from the Egyptian, and killed him with his own spear.
speaker: Narrator

text: These things Benaiah the son of Jehoiada did and won for himself a name alongside the three.
speaker: Narrator

text: He was more honored than the thirty, but he did not attain to the three. So David set him over his bodyguard.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Among the thirty were
Asahel the brother of Joab,
Elhanan the son of Dodo of Bethlehem,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Shammah the Harodite,
Elika the Harodite,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Helez the Paltite,
Ira the son of Ikkesh the Tekoite,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Abiezer the Anathothite,
Mebunnai the Hushathite,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Zalmon the Ahohite,
Maharai the Netophathite,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Heled the son of Baanah the Netophathite,
Ithai the son of Ribai from Gibeah of Benjamin,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Benaiah the Pirathonite,
Hiddai from the brooks of Gaash,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Abi-Albon the Arbathite,
Azmaveth the Barhumite,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Eliahba the Shaalbonite,
of the sons of Jashen,
Jonathan,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Shammah the Hararite,
Ahiam the son of Sharar the Hararite,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Eliphelet the son of Ahasbai, the son of the Maakathite,
Eliam the son of Ahithophel the Gilonite,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Hezro the Carmelite,
Paarai the Arbite,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Igal the son of Nathan from Zobah,
the son of Hagri,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Zelek the Ammonite,
Naharai the Beerothite, the armor bearer of Joab the son of Zeruiah,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Ira the Ithrite,
Gareb the Ithrite,
speaker: Narrator

text:
and Uriah the Hittite.
There were thirty-seven in all.
speaker: Narrator

text: Again the Lord became angry against Israel, and He incited David against them, saying, “Go and count the people of Israel and Judah.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The king said to Joab the commander of the army who was with him, “Go throughout all of the tribes of Israel, from Dan to Beersheba, and muster the people so that I may know the number of the people.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Joab said to the king, “May the Lord your God add to the people however many they are one hundred times over in the sight of my lord the king. But why does my lord the king so desire this thing?”
speaker: Narrator

text: However, the king’s word prevailed against Joab and the commanders of the army. So Joab and the commanders of the army went out from before the king to register the people of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: They crossed the Jordan and camped at Aroer, south of the city, in the middle of the ravine of Gad toward Jazer.
speaker: Narrator

text: They went toward Gilead to the land of Tahtim Hodshi. Then they went toward Dan Jaan and around to Sidon.
speaker: Narrator

text: They went to the fortress of Tyre and all of the towns of the Hivites and Canaanites. They went to the Negev and Beersheba.
speaker: Narrator

text: They went throughout the entire land, and after nine months and twenty days, they came to Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joab gave the count of the census of the people to the king. There were eight hundred thousand capable men who could draw a sword in Israel, and the men of Judah were five hundred thousand.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the heart of David struck him after he had counted the people. David said to the Lord, “I have sinned greatly by what I have done. Now may the Lord take away the iniquity of your servant, for I have behaved very foolishly.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When David arose in the morning, the word of the Lord came to the prophet Gad, the seer for David, saying,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Go and speak to David: Thus says the Lord: Three options I am laying before you. Choose for yourself one of them, and I will do this to you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Gad came to David and told him. He said to him, “Shall seven years of famine come to you in your land? Or shall you flee three months before your enemies while they pursue you? Or shall there be three days of plague in your land? Now consider and advise what answer I shall return to Him who sent me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: David said to Gad, “I am very distressed. Let us fall by the hand of the Lord, for His mercy is great. May I not fall by the hand of man.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Lord sent a plague upon Israel from the morning until the appointed time. Seventy thousand men from the people died, from Dan to Beersheba.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the angel stretched out his hand toward Jerusalem to destroy it, the Lord relented from the calamity. He said to the angel who was annihilating the people, “Enough! Now stay your hand.” The angel of the Lord was at the threshing floor of Araunah the Jebusite.
speaker: Narrator

text: On seeing the angel who was striking down the people, David said to the Lord, “I am the one who has sinned and I am the one who has done wrong. These sheep, what have they done? Please, let your hand be against me and against the house of my father.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Gad came to David that day and said to him, “Go up and erect an altar to the Lord on the threshing floor of Araunah the Jebusite.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So David went up according to the word of Gad, as the Lord commanded.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Araunah looked and saw the king and his servants coming toward him, he went out and bowed low to the king with his face on the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Araunah said, “Why has my lord the king come to his servant?”
David replied, “To purchase the threshing floor from you in order to build an altar to the Lord, so that the plague may be averted from the people.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Araunah said to David, “Let my lord the king take and offer up what seems good to him. Here are the oxen for the burnt offering and the threshing sledges and yokes of the oxen for wood.
speaker: Narrator

text: Everything, O king, Araunah gives to the king.” Araunah also said to the king, “May the Lord your God be favorable toward you.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
However, the king said to Araunah, “No, for I will certainly purchase from you for a fair price. I will not offer up to the Lord burnt offerings that cost me nothing.”
So David purchased the threshing floor and the oxen for fifty shekels of silver.
speaker: Narrator

text: David built an altar to the Lord there and offered burnt offerings and peace offerings. Then the land pleaded with the Lord, and the plague was averted from Israel.
speaker: Narrator
